questions.question: Which factors made early Republic sources more reliable than Kingdom period sources? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Early Republic sources contain less mythological material and are closer in historical time
The Twelve Tables provide contemporary written evidence to verify literary claims
All early Republic sources were written by eyewitnesses to the actual events
Early Republic sources contain no legendary or invented material
Archaeological evidence for the early Republic is more abundant than for Kingdom

questions.question: What does the absence of explicit patrician definitions in ancient sources suggest? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Patrician status was clearly defined in written law from the Republic's beginning
The patrician-plebeian distinction may have been less rigid initially than later sources suggest
Patricians deliberately hid their status from historical documentation
The distinction emerged gradually over time and became clearer as centuries passed
Ancient authors were intentionally lying about patrician existence

questions.question: Which statement best captures the key difference between Kingdom and Republic power structures?
options: Both systems concentrated power in a single individual but paid different salaries
Kingdom had one ruler answerable to none; Republic distributed power among multiple officials
Republic had a king while Kingdom government was controlled by tribunes
Kingdom allowed popular assemblies while Republic gave power only to patricians
Both systems were essentially identical in their fundamental governmental structure

questions.question: What paradox existed in the Comitia Centuriata as an instrument of 'popular participation'?
options: Wealthy citizens and poor citizens had exactly equal voting power in every instance
It gave formal voting rights to all citizens while concentrating power among the wealthy
It gave all voting power to plebeians and none to patrician citizens
Poor citizens had significantly more voting power than wealthy patrician citizens
It was specifically designed to prevent all patricians from holding office
questions.text_reference: Section 1: Assemblies - Popular Participation, Aristocratic Advantage

questions.question: Which interpretation is MOST supported by historical evidence for the Conflict of the Orders?
options: All reforms definitely happened at the exact dates ancient sources provide
No reforms ever happened because the entire Conflict is invented and fictional
Broad plebeian rights expansion is confirmed, but specific dates and incidents may be misremembered
Plebeians gained all political rights immediately when the Republic began
Only written sources matter; archaeology tells us nothing about the early Republic
questions.text_reference: Section 2: Modern Historical Approach and The Conflict of the Orders

questions.question: Which aspects represented genuine innovation rather than traditional custom? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Distribution of executive power between two equal magistrates with mutual veto
Systematic limitation of magistrate terms to one year maximum
Post-term accountability for magistrates through legal prosecution
Creating a magistracy specifically to protect plebeians against the elite
Preservation of unwritten ancestral custom (*mos maiorum*) as fundamental law

questions.question: Why was written law NECESSARY but INSUFFICIENT to resolve the patrician-plebeian conflict?
options: Written law immediately ended all patrician-plebeian political conflict completely
The Twelve Tables abolished the Senate as the ruling governing body
Written law prevented arbitrary interpretation but not plebeian exclusion from magistracies
Plebeians rejected written law and demanded to return to oral tradition
The Twelve Tables gave all political power to plebeians immediately
questions.text_reference: Section 5: The Limitations and The Bridge

questions.question: Which reasons explain why mutual veto was preferable to character-based reliance? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Structural safeguards are more reliable than trusting in individual personal virtue
Even a virtuous consul could be constrained by his colleague to prevent abuse
Power concentrated in any single office was considered inherently and fundamentally dangerous
Mutual veto eliminated any need for a Senate to advise magistrates
Plebeians could serve as consuls immediately with mutual veto in place
questions.text_reference: Section 1: Why Two Consuls and The Immediate Challenge

questions.question: What does the challenge of evaluating early Republic sources reveal about historical methodology?
options: Ancient sources are always completely accurate in every detail provided
Historians should ignore ancient sources entirely and rely only on archaeology
Historians must use multiple evidence types critically, recognizing bias and legendary material
Modern historians know more than ancient authors so we dismiss accounts entirely
All historical claims about the past are equally valid regardless of available evidence

questions.question: Why did patrician incremental concessions ultimately fail to prevent plebeian success? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Concessions created precedent encouraging plebeians to demand additional reforms
Plebeians rejected all offers and demanded violent revolutionary change instead
The strategy delayed but could not prevent eventual loss of patrician monopoly
The tribunes immediately took over the entire government after first concession
Plebeians gradually gained enough political power to challenge patrician dominance
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Patrician Response and Section 5: The Bridge
